To simplify the expression, we can factor out a common term from the numerator:

$$\frac{\sin^2(x) - \cos^2(x)}{\sin(x) - \cos(x)} = \frac{(\sin(x) + \cos(x))(\sin(x) - \cos(x))}{\sin(x) - \cos(x)}$$

Now, we can cancel out the common term $(\sin(x) - \cos(x))$ from the numerator and denominator:

$$\frac{(\sin(x) + \cos(x))(\sin(x) - \cos(x))}{\sin(x) - \cos(x)} = \sin(x) + \cos(x)$$

So, the simplified expression is:

$$\sin(x) + \cos(x)$$
